pt: {sc}sarcastic{/sc} {sc}satiric{/sc} {sc}ironic{/sc} {sc}sardonic{/sc} mean marked by bitterness and a power or will to cut or sting. {sc}sarcastic{/sc} implies an intentional inflicting of pain by deriding, taunting, or ridiculing.

pt.t: a critic known for his {it}sarcastic{/it} remarks

pt: {sc}satiric{/sc} implies that the intent of the ridiculing is censure and reprobation.
{sc}ironic{/sc} implies an attempt to be amusing or provocative by saying usually the opposite of what is meant.

pt.t: made the {it}ironic{/it} observation that the government could always be trusted

pt: {sc}sardonic{/sc} implies scorn, mockery, or derision that is manifested by either verbal or facial expression.

pt.t: surveyed the scene with a {it}sardonic{/it} smile

quotes.t: DeWitt is everything Shea is not. And Shea quickly felt DeWitt's contempt. "Lincoln is loud," Jim says. "He makes {qword}sarcastic{/qword} comments because he has to call attention to himself all the time. Some people are insecure because they haven't established themselves yet."

Frank evokes the eccentric Hamilton family and their feisty Gullah housekeeper with originality and conviction; Susan herself—smart, {qword}sarcastic{/qword}, funny and endearingly flawed—makes a lively and memorable narrator.

Close on the heels of "Millionaire" came "The Weakest Link," which added a new wrinkle (subsequently picked up by "American Idol"): Its British host, Anne Robinson, was presented not as a genteel, erudite tutor but rather as a rude, {qword}sarcastic{/qword} jerk.
